text: Paul, called to be an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, and our brother Sosthenes,
speaker: Narrator

text: To the church of God that is in Corinth, to those who are sanctified in Christ Jesus, called to be saints, together with all those who in every place call on the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, both their Lord and ours:
speaker: Narrator

text: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: I give thanks to my God always for you because of the grace of God that has been given you in Christ Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: for in every way you have been enriched in him, in speech and knowledge of every kind—
speaker: Narrator

text: just as the testimony of Christ has been strengthened among you—
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you are not lacking in any gift as you wait for the revealing of our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will also strengthen you to the end, so that you may be blameless on the day of our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: God is faithful, by whom you were called into the partnership of his Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I appeal to you, brothers and sisters, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you be in agreement and that there be no divisions among you but that you be knit together in the same mind and the same purpose.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it has been made clear to me by Chloe’s people that there are quarrels among you, my brothers and sisters.
speaker: Narrator

text: What I mean is that each of you says, “I belong to Paul,” or “I belong to Apollos,” or “I belong to Cephas,” or “I belong to Christ.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Has Christ been divided? Was Paul crucified for you? Or were you baptized in the name of Paul?
speaker: Narrator

text: I thank God that I baptized none of you except Crispus and Gaius,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that no one can say that you were baptized in my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: I did baptize also the household of Stephanas; beyond that, I do not know whether I baptized anyone else.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Christ did not send me to baptize but to proclaim the gospel—and not with eloquent wisdom, so that the cross of Christ might not be emptied of its power.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the message about the cross is foolishness to those who are perishing, but to us who are being saved it is the power of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it is written,
“I will destroy the wisdom of the wise,
    and the discernment of the discerning I will thwart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Where is the one who is wise? Where is the scholar? Where is the debater of this age? Has not God made foolish the wisdom of the world?
speaker: Narrator

text: For since, in the wisdom of God, the world did not know God through wisdom, God decided, through the foolishness of the proclamation, to save those who believe.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Jews ask for signs and Greeks desire wisdom,
speaker: Narrator

text: but we proclaim Christ crucified, a stumbling block to Jews and foolishness to gentiles,
speaker: Narrator

text: but to those who are the called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God and the wisdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God’s foolishness is wiser than human wisdom, and God’s weakness is stronger than human strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: Consider your own call, brothers and sisters: not many of you were wise by human standards, not many were powerful, not many were of noble birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God chose what is foolish in the world to shame the wise; God chose what is weak in the world to shame the strong;
speaker: Narrator

text: God chose what is low and despised in the world, things that are not, to abolish things that are,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that no one might boast in the presence of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: In contrast, God is why you are in Christ Jesus, who became for us wisdom from God, and righteousness and sanctification and redemption,
speaker: Narrator

text: in order that, as it is written, “Let the one who boasts, boast in the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When I came to you, brothers and sisters, I did not come proclaiming the testimony of God to you with superior speech or wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I decided to know nothing among you except Jesus Christ and him crucified.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I came to you in weakness and in fear and in much trembling.
speaker: Narrator

text: My speech and my proclamation were made not with persuasive words of wisdom but with a demonstration of the Spirit and of power,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that your faith might rest not on human wisdom but on the power of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet among the mature we do speak wisdom, though it is not a wisdom of this age or of the rulers of this age, who are being destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we speak God’s wisdom, a hidden mystery, which God decreed before the ages for our glory
speaker: Narrator

text: and which none of the rulers of this age understood, for if they had, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But, as it is written,
“What no eye has seen, nor ear heard,
    nor the human heart conceived,
what God has prepared for those who love him”—
speaker: Narrator

text: God has revealed to us through the Spirit, for the Spirit searches everything, even the depths of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what human knows what is truly human except the human spirit that is within? So also no one comprehends what is truly God’s except the Spirit of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now we have received not the spirit of the world but the Spirit that is from God, so that we may understand the gifts bestowed on us by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we speak of these things in words not taught by human wisdom but taught by the Spirit, interpreting spiritual things to those who are spiritual.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are unspiritual do not receive the gifts of God’s Spirit, for they are foolishness to them, and they are unable to understand them because they are spiritually discerned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are spiritual discern all things, and they are themselves subject to no one else’s scrutiny.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For who has known the mind of the Lord
    so as to instruct him?”
But we have the mind of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so, brothers and sisters, I could not speak to you as spiritual people but rather as fleshly, as infants in Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: I fed you with milk, not solid food, for you were not ready for solid food. Even now you are still not ready,
speaker: Narrator

text: for you are still fleshly. For as long as there is jealousy and quarreling among you, are you not fleshly and behaving according to human inclinations?
speaker: Narrator

text: For when one says, “I belong to Paul,” and another, “I belong to Apollos,” are you not all too human?
speaker: Narrator

text: What then is Apollos? What is Paul? Servants through whom you came to believe, as the Lord assigned to each.
speaker: Narrator

text: I planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the growth.
speaker: Narrator

text: So neither the one who plants nor the one who waters is anything, but only God who gives the growth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who plants and the one who waters have one purpose, and each will receive wages according to their own labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we are God’s coworkers, working together; you are God’s field, God’s building.
speaker: Narrator

text: According to the grace of God given to me, like a wise master builder I laid a foundation, and someone else is building on it. Let each builder choose with care how to build on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For no one can lay any foundation other than the one that has been laid; that foundation is Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if anyone builds on the foundation with gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, straw—
speaker: Narrator

text: the work of each builder will become visible, for the day will disclose it, because it will be revealed with fire, and the fire will test what sort of work each has done.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the work that someone has built on the foundation survives, the builder will receive a wage.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the work is burned up, the builder will suffer loss; the builder will be saved, but only as through fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that you are God’s temple and that God’s Spirit dwells in you?
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone destroys God’s temple, God will destroy that person. For God’s temple is holy, and you are that temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not deceive yourselves. If you think that you are wise in this age, you should become fools so that you may become wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God. For it is written,
“He catches the wise in their craftiness,”
speaker: Narrator

text:
and again,
“The Lord knows the thoughts of the wise,
    that they are futile.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So let no one boast about people. For all things are yours,
speaker: Narrator

text: whether Paul or Apollos or Cephas or the world or life or death or the present or the future—all are yours,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you are Christ’s, and Christ is God’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: Think of us in this way: as servants of Christ and stewards of God’s mysteries.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, it is required of stewards that they be found trustworthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: But with me it is a very small thing that I should be judged by you or by any human court. I do not even judge myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not aware of anything against myself, but I am not thereby acquitted. It is the Lord who judges me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore do not pronounce judgment before the time, before the Lord comes, who will bring to light the things now hidden in darkness and will disclose the purposes of the heart. Then each one will receive commendation from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have applied all this to Apollos and myself for your benefit, brothers and sisters, so that you may learn through us what “Not beyond what is written” means, so that none of you will be puffed up in favor of one against another.
speaker: Narrator

text: For who sees anything different in you? What do you have that you did not receive? And if you received it, why do you boast as if you did not receive?
speaker: Narrator

text: Already you have all you want! Already you have become rich! Quite apart from us you have become kings! If only you had become kings, so that we might be kings with you!
speaker: Narrator

text: For I think that God has exhibited us apostles as last of all, as though sentenced to death, because we have become a spectacle to the world, to angels and to humans.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are fools for the sake of Christ, but you are sensible people in Christ. We are weak, but you are strong. You are honored, but we are dishonored.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the present hour we are hungry and thirsty, we are naked and beaten and homeless,
speaker: Narrator

text: and we grow weary from the work of our own hands. When reviled, we bless; when persecuted, we endure;
speaker: Narrator

text: when slandered, we speak kindly. We have become like the rubbish of the world, the dregs of all things, to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not writing this to make you ashamed but to admonish you as my beloved children.
speaker: Narrator

text: For though you might have ten thousand guardians in Christ, you do not have many fathers. Indeed, in Christ Jesus I fathered you through the gospel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I appeal to you, then, be imitators of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason I sent you Timothy, who is my beloved and trustworthy child in the Lord, to remind you of my ways in Christ Jesus, as I teach them everywhere in every church.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some of you, thinking that I am not coming to you, have become arrogant.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will come to you soon, if the Lord wills, and I will find out not the talk of these arrogant people but their power.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the kingdom of God depends not on talk but on power.
speaker: Narrator

text: What would you prefer? Am I to come to you with a stick or with love in a spirit of gentleness?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is actually reported that there is sexual immorality among you and the sort of sexual immorality that is not found even among gentiles, for a man is living with his father’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you are arrogant! Should you not rather have mourned, so that he who has done this would have been removed from among you?
speaker: Narrator

text: For I, though absent in body, am present in spirit, and as if present I have already pronounced judgment
speaker: Narrator

text: in the name of the Lord Jesus on the man who has done such a thing. When you are assembled and my spirit is present with the power of our Lord Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: you are to hand this man over to Satan for the destruction of the flesh, so that the spirit may be saved in the day of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your boasting is not a good thing. Do you not know that a little yeast leavens all of the dough?
speaker: Narrator

text: Clean out the old yeast so that you may be a new batch of dough, as you really are unleavened. For our paschal lamb, Christ, has been sacrificed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, let us celebrate the festival, not with the old yeast, the yeast of malice and evil, but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I wrote to you in my letter not to associate with sexually immoral persons,
speaker: Narrator

text: not at all meaning the sexually immoral of this world, or the greedy and swindlers, or idolaters, since you would then need to go out of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now I am writing to you not to associate with anyone who bears the name of brother or sister who is sexually immoral or greedy or an idolater, reviler, drunkard, or swindler. Do not even eat with such a one.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what have I to do with judging those outside? Are you not judges of those who are inside?
speaker: Narrator

text: God will judge those outside. “Drive out the wicked person from among you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When any of you has a grievance against another, do you dare to take it to court before the unrighteous, instead of taking it before the saints?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that the saints will judge the world? And if the world is to be judged by you, are you incompetent to try trivial cases?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that we are to judge angels, to say nothing of ordinary matters?
speaker: Narrator

text: If you have ordinary cases, then, do you appoint as judges those who have no standing in the church?
speaker: Narrator

text: I say this to your shame. Can it be that there is no one person wise enough to decide between brothers and sisters?
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, brothers and sisters go to court against one another, and this before the unbelievers.
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, to have lawsuits at all with one another is already a defeat for you. Why not rather be wronged? Why not rather be defrauded?
speaker: Narrator

text: But you yourselves wrong and defraud—and brothers and sisters at that.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that wrongdoers will not inherit the kingdom of God? Do not be deceived! The sexually immoral, idolaters, adulterers, male prostitutes, men who engage in illicit sex,
speaker: Narrator

text: thieves, the greedy, drunkards, revilers, swindlers—none of these will inherit the kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this is what some of you used to be. But you were washed, you were sanctified, you were justified in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ and in the Spirit of our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All things are permitted for me,” but not all things are beneficial. “All things are permitted for me,” but I will not be dominated by anything.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Food is meant for the stomach and the stomach for food,” and God will destroy both one and the other. The body is meant not for sexual immorality but for the Lord and the Lord for the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God raised the Lord and will also raise us by his power.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that your bodies are members of Christ? Should I therefore take the members of Christ and make them members of a prostitute? Never!
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that whoever is united to a prostitute becomes one body with her? For it is said, “The two shall be one flesh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But anyone united to the Lord becomes one spirit with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shun sexual immorality! Every sin that a person commits is outside the body, but the sexually immoral person sins against the body itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit within you, which you have from God, and that you are not your own?
speaker: Narrator

text: For you were bought with a price; therefore glorify God in your body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning the matters about which you wrote: “It is good for a man not to touch a woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But because of cases of sexual immorality, each man should have his own wife and each woman her own husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: The husband should give to his wife what is due her and likewise the wife to her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the wife does not have authority over her own body, but the husband does; likewise, the husband does not have authority over his own body, but the wife does.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not deprive one another except perhaps by agreement for a set time, to devote yourselves to prayer, and then come together again, so that Satan may not tempt you because of your lack of self-control.
speaker: Narrator

text: This I say by way of concession, not of command.
speaker: Narrator

text: I wish that all were as I myself am. But each has a particular gift from God, one having one kind and another a different kind.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the unmarried and the widows I say that it is good for them to remain unmarried as I am.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they are not practicing self-control, they should marry. For it is better to marry than to be aflame with passion.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the married I give this command—not I but the Lord—that the wife should not separate from her husband
speaker: Narrator

text: (but if she does separate, let her remain unmarried or else be reconciled to her husband) and that the husband should not divorce his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the rest I say—I and not the Lord—that if any brother has a wife who is an unbeliever and she consents to live with him, he should not divorce her.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if any woman has a husband who is an unbeliever and he consents to live with her, she should not divorce the husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the unbelieving husband is made holy through his wife, and the unbelieving wife is made holy through the brother. Otherwise, your children would be unclean, but as it is, they are holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the unbelieving partner separates, let it be so; in such a case the brother or sister is not bound. It is to peace that God has called us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wife, for all you know, you might save your husband. Husband, for all you know, you might save your wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: However that may be, let each of you lead the life that the Lord has assigned, to which God called you. This is my rule in all the churches.
speaker: Narrator

text: Was anyone at the time of his call already circumcised? Let him not seek to remove the marks of circumcision. Was anyone at the time of his call uncircumcised? Let him not seek circumcision.
speaker: Narrator

text: Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing, but obeying the commandments of God is everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let each of you remain in the condition in which you were called.
speaker: Narrator

text: Were you a slave when called? Do not be concerned about it. Even if you can gain your freedom, make the most of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whoever was called in the Lord as a slave is a freed person belonging to the Lord, just as whoever was free when called is a slave belonging to Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: You were bought with a price; do not become slaves of humans.
speaker: Narrator

text: In whatever condition you were called, brothers and sisters, there remain with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning virgins, I have no command of the Lord, but I give my opinion as one who by the Lord’s mercy is trustworthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: I think that, in view of the impending crisis, it is good for you to remain as you are.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you bound to a wife? Do not seek to be free. Are you free from a wife? Do not seek a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you marry, you do not sin, and if a virgin marries, she does not sin. Yet those who marry will experience distress in the flesh, and I would spare you that.
speaker: Narrator

text: I mean, brothers and sisters, the appointed time has grown short; from now on, let even those who have wives be as though they had none,
speaker: Narrator

text: and those who mourn as though they were not mourning, and those who rejoice as though they were not rejoicing, and those who buy as though they had no possessions,
speaker: Narrator

text: and those who deal with the world as though they had no dealings with it. For the present form of this world is passing away.
speaker: Narrator

text: I want you to be free from anxieties. The unmarried man is anxious about the affairs of the Lord, how to please the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the married man is anxious about the affairs of the world, how to please his wife,
speaker: Narrator

text: and his interests are divided. And the unmarried woman and the virgin are anxious about the affairs of the Lord, so that they may be holy in body and spirit, but the married woman is anxious about the affairs of the world, how to please her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: I say this for your own benefit, not to put any restraint upon you but to promote good order and unhindered devotion to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone thinks that he is behaving indecently toward his fiancée, if his passions are strong and so it has to be, let him marry as he wishes; it is no sin. Let them marry.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if someone stands firm in his resolve, being under no necessity but having his own desire under control, and has determined in his own mind to keep her as his fiancée, he will do well.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, he who marries his fiancée does well, and he who refrains from marriage will do better.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wife is bound as long as her husband lives. But if the husband dies, she is free to marry anyone she wishes, only in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in my opinion she is more blessed if she remains as she is. And I think that I, too, have the Spirit of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning food sacrificed to idols: we know that “all of us possess knowledge.” Knowledge puffs up, but love builds up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who claims to know something does not yet have the necessary knowledge,
speaker: Narrator

text: but anyone who loves God is known by him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hence, as to the eating of food offered to idols, we know that “no idol in the world really exists” and that “there is no God but one.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, even though there may be so-called gods in heaven or on earth—as in fact there are many gods and many lords—
speaker: Narrator

text: yet for us there is one God, the Father, from whom are all things and for whom we exist, and one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom are all things and through whom we exist.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not everyone, however, who has this knowledge. Since some have become so accustomed to idols until now, they still think of the food they eat as food offered to an idol, and their conscience, being weak, is defiled.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Food will not bring us close to God.” We are no worse off if we do not eat and no better off if we do.
speaker: Narrator

text: But take care that this liberty of yours does not somehow become a stumbling block to the weak.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if others see you, who possess knowledge, eating in the temple of an idol, might they not, since their conscience is weak, be encouraged to the point of eating food sacrificed to idols?
speaker: Narrator

text: So by your knowledge the weak brother or sister for whom Christ died is destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when you thus sin against brothers and sisters and wound their conscience when it is weak, you sin against Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, if food is a cause of their falling, I will never again eat meat, so that I may not cause one of them to fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: Am I not free? Am I not an apostle? Have I not seen Jesus our Lord? Are you not my work in the Lord?
speaker: Narrator

text: If I am not an apostle to others, at least I am to you, for you are the seal of my apostleship in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is my defense to those who would examine me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do we not have the right to our food and drink?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do we not have the right to be accompanied by a believing wife, as do the other apostles and the brothers of the Lord and Cephas?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or is it only Barnabas and I who have no right to refrain from working for a living?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who at any time pays the expenses for doing military service? Who plants a vineyard and does not eat any of its fruit? Or who tends a flock and does not get any of its milk?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do I say this on human authority? Does not the law also say the same?
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is written in the law of Moses, “You shall not muzzle an ox while it is treading out the grain.” Is it for oxen that God is concerned?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or does he not speak entirely for our sake? It was indeed written for our sake, for whoever plows should plow in hope and whoever threshes should thresh in hope of a share in the crop.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we have sown spiritual things among you, is it too much if we harvest material things?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If others share this rightful claim on you, do not we still more?
Nevertheless, we have not made use of this right, but we endure anything rather than put an obstacle in the way of the gospel of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that those who work in the temple service get their food from the temple and those who serve at the altar share in what is sacrificed on the altar?
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, the Lord commanded that those who proclaim the gospel should get their living by the gospel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have made no use of any of these rights, nor am I writing this so that they may be applied in my case. Indeed, I would rather die than that—no one will deprive me of my ground for boasting!
speaker: Narrator

text: If I proclaim the gospel, this gives me no ground for boasting, for an obligation is laid on me, and woe to me if I do not proclaim the gospel!
speaker: Narrator

text: For if I do this of my own will, I have a wage, but if not of my own will, I am entrusted with a commission.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then is my wage? Just this: that in my proclamation I may make the gospel free of charge, so as not to make full use of my rights in the gospel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For though I am free with respect to all, I have made myself a slave to all, so that I might gain all the more.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the Jews I became as a Jew, in order to gain Jews. To those under the law I became as one under the law (though I myself am not under the law) so that I might gain those under the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: To those outside the law I became as one outside the law (though I am not outside God’s law but am within Christ’s law) so that I might gain those outside the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the weak I became weak, so that I might gain the weak. I have become all things to all people, that I might by all means save some.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do it all for the sake of the gospel, so that I might become a partner in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that in a race the runners all compete, but only one receives the prize? Run in such a way that you may win it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Athletes exercise self-control in all things; they do it to receive a perishable wreath, but we an imperishable one.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I do not run aimlessly, nor do I box as though beating the air,
speaker: Narrator

text: but I punish my body and enslave it, so that after proclaiming to others I myself should not be disqualified.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do not want you to be ignorant, brothers and sisters, that our ancestors were all under the cloud, and all passed through the sea,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all were baptized into Moses in the cloud and in the sea,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all ate the same spiritual food,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all drank the same spiritual drink. For they drank from the spiritual rock that followed them, and the rock was Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, God was not pleased with most of them, and they were struck down in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these things occurred as examples for us, so that we might not desire evil as they did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not become idolaters as some of them did, as it is written, “The people sat down to eat and drink, and they rose up to play.”
speaker: Narrator

text: We must not engage in sexual immorality, as some of them did, and twenty-three thousand fell in a single day.
speaker: Narrator

text: We must not put Christ to the test, as some of them did, and were destroyed by serpents.
speaker: Narrator

text: And do not complain, as some of them did, and were destroyed by the destroyer.
speaker: Narrator

text: These things happened to them to serve as an example, and they were written down to instruct us, on whom the ends of the ages have come.
speaker: Narrator

text: So if you think you are standing, watch out that you do not fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: No testing has overtaken you that is not common to everyone. God is faithful, and he will not let you be tested beyond your strength, but with the testing he will also provide the way out so that you may be able to endure it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, my beloved, flee from the worship of idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I speak as to sensible people; judge for yourselves what I say.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cup of blessing that we bless, is it not a sharing in the blood of Christ? The bread that we break, is it not a sharing in the body of Christ?
speaker: Narrator

text: Because there is one bread, we who are many are one body, for we all partake of the one bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: Consider the people of Israel: Are not those who eat the sacrifices partners in the altar?
speaker: Narrator

text: What do I imply, then? That food sacrificed to idols is anything or that an idol is anything?
speaker: Narrator

text: No, I imply that what they sacrifice, they sacrifice to demons and not to God. I do not want you to be partners with demons.
speaker: Narrator

text: You cannot drink the cup of the Lord and the cup of demons. You cannot partake of the table of the Lord and the table of demons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or are we provoking the Lord to jealousy? Are we stronger than he?
speaker: Narrator

text: “All things are permitted,” but not all things are beneficial. “All things are permitted,” but not all things build up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not seek your own advantage but that of the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat whatever is sold in the meat market without raising any question on the ground of conscience,
speaker: Narrator

text: for “the earth and its fullness are the Lord’s.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If an unbeliever invites you to a meal and you are disposed to go, eat whatever is set before you without raising any question on the ground of conscience.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if someone says to you, “This has been offered in sacrifice,” then do not eat it, out of consideration for the one who informed you and for the sake of conscience—
speaker: Narrator

text: I mean the other’s conscience, not your own. For why should my freedom be subject to the judgment of someone else’s conscience?
speaker: Narrator

text: If I partake with thankfulness, why should I be denounced because of that for which I give thanks?
speaker: Narrator

text: So, whether you eat or drink or whatever you do, do everything for the glory of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give no offense to Jews or to Greeks or to the church of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: just as I try to please everyone in everything I do, not seeking my own advantage but that of many, so that they may be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be imitators of me, as I am of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: I commend you because you remember me in everything and maintain the traditions just as I handed them on to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I want you to understand that Christ is the head of every man, and the man is the head of the woman, and God is the head of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any man who prays or prophesies with something on his head shames his head,
speaker: Narrator

text: but any woman who prays or prophesies with her head unveiled shames her head—it is one and the same thing as having her head shaved.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if a woman will not veil herself, then she should cut off her hair, but if it is shameful for a woman to have her hair cut off or to be shaved, she should wear a veil.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a man ought not to have his head veiled, since he is the image and reflection of God, but woman is the reflection of man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, man was not made from woman but woman from man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither was man created for the sake of woman but woman for the sake of man.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason a woman ought to have authority over her head, because of the angels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, in the Lord woman is not independent of man or man independent of woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as woman came from man, so man comes through woman, but all things come from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judge for yourselves: Is it proper for a woman to pray to God with her head unveiled?
speaker: Narrator

text: Does not nature itself teach you that, if a man wears long hair, it is dishonoring to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: but if a woman has long hair, it is her glory? For her hair is given to her for a covering.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if anyone is disposed to be contentious—we have no such custom, nor do the churches of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now in the following instructions I do not commend you, because when you come together it is not for the better but for the worse.
speaker: Narrator

text: For, to begin with, when you come together as a church, I hear that there are divisions among you, and to some extent I believe it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, there have to be factions among you, for only so will it become clear who among you are genuine.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you come together, it is not really to eat the Lord’s supper.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when the time comes to eat, each of you proceeds to eat your own supper, and one goes hungry and another becomes drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text: What! Do you not have households to eat and drink in? Or do you show contempt for the church of God and humiliate those who have nothing? What should I say to you? Should I commend you? In this matter I do not commend you!
speaker: Narrator

text: For I received from the Lord what I also handed on to you, that the Lord Jesus on the night when he was betrayed took a loaf of bread,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when he had given thanks, he broke it and said, “This is my body that is for you. Do this in remembrance of me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way he took the cup also, after supper, saying, “This cup is the new covenant in my blood. Do this, as often as you drink it, in remembrance of me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For as often as you eat this bread and drink the cup, you proclaim the Lord’s death until he comes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever, therefore, eats the bread or drinks the cup of the Lord in an unworthy manner will be answerable for the body and blood of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Examine yourselves, and only then eat of the bread and drink of the cup.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all who eat and drink without discerning the body eat and drink judgment against themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason many of you are weak and ill, and some have died.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we judged ourselves, we would not be judged.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when we are judged by the Lord, we are disciplined so that we may not be condemned along with the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, my brothers and sisters, when you come together to eat, wait for one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you are hungry, eat at home, so that when you come together, it will not be for your condemnation. About the other things I will give instructions when I come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning spiritual gifts, brothers and sisters, I do not want you to be ignorant.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that when you were gentiles you were enticed and led astray to idols that could not speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I want you to understand that no one speaking by the Spirit of God ever says “Let Jesus be cursed!” and no one can say “Jesus is Lord” except by the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there are varieties of gifts but the same Spirit,
speaker: Narrator

text: and there are varieties of services but the same Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and there are varieties of activities, but it is the same God who activates all of them in everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: To each is given the manifestation of the Spirit for the common good.
speaker: Narrator

text: To one is given through the Spirit the utterance of wisdom and to another the utterance of knowledge according to the same Spirit,
speaker: Narrator

text: to another faith by the same Spirit, to another gifts of healing by the one Spirit,
speaker: Narrator

text: to another the working of powerful deeds, to another prophecy, to another the discernment of spirits, to another various kinds of tongues, to another the interpretation of tongues.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these are activated by one and the same Spirit, who allots to each one individually just as the Spirit chooses.
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as the body is one and has many members, and all the members of the body, though many, are one body, so it is with Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in the one Spirit we were all baptized into one body—Jews or Greeks, slaves or free—and we were all made to drink of one Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, the body does not consist of one member but of many.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the foot would say, “Because I am not a hand, I do not belong to the body,” that would not make it any less a part of the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if the ear would say, “Because I am not an eye, I do not belong to the body,” that would not make it any less a part of the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the whole body were an eye, where would the hearing be? If the whole body were hearing, where would the sense of smell be?
speaker: Narrator

text: But as it is, God arranged the members in the body, each one of them, as he chose.
speaker: Narrator

text: If all were a single member, where would the body be?
speaker: Narrator

text: As it is, there are many members yet one body.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eye cannot say to the hand, “I have no need of you,” nor again the head to the feet, “I have no need of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the contrary, the members of the body that seem to be weaker are indispensable,
speaker: Narrator

text: and those members of the body that we think less honorable we clothe with greater honor, and our less respectable members are treated with greater respect,
speaker: Narrator

text: whereas our more respectable members do not need this. But God has so arranged the body, giving the greater honor to the inferior member,
speaker: Narrator

text: that there may be no dissension within the body, but the members may have the same care for one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: If one member suffers, all suffer together with it; if one member is honored, all rejoice together with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you are the body of Christ and individually members of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God has appointed in the church first apostles, second prophets, third teachers, then deeds of power, then gifts of healing, forms of assistance, forms of leadership, various kinds of tongues.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are all apostles? Are all prophets? Are all teachers? Do all work powerful deeds?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do all possess gifts of healing? Do all speak in tongues? Do all interpret?
speaker: Narrator

text: But strive for the greater gifts. And I will show you a still more excellent way.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I speak in the tongues of humans and of angels but do not have love, I am a noisy gong or a clanging cymbal.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if I have prophetic powers and understand all mysteries and all knowledge and if I have all faith so as to remove mountains but do not have love, I am nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I give away all my possessions and if I hand over my body so that I may boast but do not have love, I gain nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Love is patient; love is kind; love is not envious or boastful or arrogant
speaker: Narrator

text: or rude. It does not insist on its own way; it is not irritable; it keeps no record of wrongs;
speaker: Narrator

text: it does not rejoice in wrongdoing but rejoices in the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: It bears all things, believes all things, hopes all things, endures all things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Love never ends. But as for prophecies, they will come to an end; as for tongues, they will cease; as for knowledge, it will come to an end.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we know only in part, and we prophesy only in part,
speaker: Narrator

text: but when the complete comes, the partial will come to an end.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I was a child, I spoke like a child, I thought like a child, I reasoned like a child. When I became an adult, I put an end to childish ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: For now we see only a reflection, as in a mirror, but then we will see face to face. Now I know only in part; then I will know fully, even as I have been fully known.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now faith, hope, and love remain, these three, and the greatest of these is love.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pursue love and strive for the spiritual gifts and especially that you may prophesy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those who speak in a tongue do not speak to other people but to God, for no one understands them, since they are speaking mysteries in the Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: But those who prophesy speak to other people for their upbuilding and encouragement and consolation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who speak in a tongue build up themselves, but those who prophesy build up the church.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I would like all of you to speak in tongues but even more to prophesy. One who prophesies is greater than one who speaks in tongues, unless someone interprets, so that the church may be built up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, brothers and sisters, if I come to you speaking in tongues, how will I benefit you unless I speak to you in some revelation or knowledge or prophecy or teaching?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is the same way with lifeless instruments that produce sound, such as the flute or the harp. If they do not give distinct notes, how will what is being played on the flute or harp be recognized?
speaker: Narrator

text: And if the bugle gives an indistinct sound, who will get ready for battle?
speaker: Narrator

text: So with yourselves: If in a tongue you utter speech that is not intelligible, how will anyone know what is being said? For you will be speaking into the air.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are doubtless many different kinds of sounds in the world, and nothing is without sound.
speaker: Narrator

text: If then I do not know the meaning of a sound, I will be a foreigner to the speaker and the speaker a foreigner to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So with yourselves: since you are striving after spiritual gifts, seek to excel in them for building up the church.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, one who speaks in a tongue should pray for the power to interpret.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if I pray in a tongue, my spirit prays but my mind is unproductive.
speaker: Narrator

text: What should I do then? I will pray with the spirit, but I will pray with the mind also; I will sing praise with the spirit, but I will sing praise with the mind also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, if you say a blessing with the spirit, how can anyone in the position of an outsider say the “Amen” to your thanksgiving, since the outsider does not know what you are saying?
speaker: Narrator

text: For you may give thanks well enough, but the other person is not built up.
speaker: Narrator

text: I thank God that I speak in tongues more than all of you;
speaker: Narrator

text: nevertheless, in church I would rather speak five words with my mind, in order to instruct others also, than ten thousand words in a tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers and sisters, do not be children in your thinking; rather, be infants in evil, but in thinking be adults.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the law it is written,
“By people of strange tongues
    and by the lips of foreigners
I will speak to this people,
    yet even then they will not listen to me,”
says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tongues, then, are a sign not for believers but for unbelievers, while prophecy is not for unbelievers but for believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, therefore, the entire church comes together and all speak in tongues, and outsiders or unbelievers enter, will they not say that you are out of your mind?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if all prophesy, an unbeliever or outsider who enters is reproved by all and called to account by all.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the secrets of the unbeliever’s heart are disclosed, that person will bow down before God and worship, declaring, “God is really among you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What should be done then, my brothers and sisters? When you come together, each one has a hymn, a lesson, a revelation, a tongue, or an interpretation. Let all things be done for building up.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone speaks in a tongue, let there be only two or at most three and each in turn, and let one interpret.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if there is no one to interpret, let them be silent in church and speak to themselves and to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let two or three prophets speak, and let the others weigh what is said.
speaker: Narrator

text: If someone sitting receives a revelation, let the first person be silent.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you can all prophesy one by one, so that all may learn and all be encouraged
speaker: Narrator

text: (and the spirits of prophets are subject to the prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text: for God is a God not of disorder but of peace), as in all the churches of the saints.
speaker: Narrator

text: Women should be silent in the churches. For they are not permitted to speak but should be subordinate, as the law also says.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there is something they want to learn, let them ask their husbands at home. For it is shameful for a woman to speak in church.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or did the word of God originate with you? Or are you the only ones it has reached?
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who claims to be a prophet or spiritual must acknowledge that what I am writing to you is a command of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who does not recognize this is not to be recognized.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, my brothers and sisters, strive to prophesy, and do not forbid speaking in tongues,
speaker: Narrator

text: but all things should be done decently and in order.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I want you to understand, brothers and sisters, the good news that I proclaimed to you, which you in turn received, in which also you stand,
speaker: Narrator

text: through which also you are being saved, if you hold firmly to the message that I proclaimed to you—unless you have come to believe in vain.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I handed on to you as of first importance what I in turn had received: that Christ died for our sins in accordance with the scriptures
speaker: Narrator

text: and that he was buried and that he was raised on the third day in accordance with the scriptures
speaker: Narrator

text: and that he appeared to Cephas, then to the twelve.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he appeared to more than five hundred brothers and sisters at one time, most of whom are still alive, though some have died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he appeared to James, then to all the apostles.
speaker: Narrator

text: Last of all, as to one untimely born, he appeared also to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am the least of the apostles, unfit to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But by the grace of God I am what I am, and his grace toward me has not been in vain. On the contrary, I worked harder than any of them, though it was not I but the grace of God that is with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whether then it was I or they, so we proclaim and so you believed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if Christ is proclaimed as raised from the dead, how can some of you say there is no resurrection of the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: If there is no resurrection of the dead, then Christ has not been raised,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if Christ has not been raised, then our proclamation is in vain and your faith is in vain.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are even found to be misrepresenting God, because we testified of God that he raised Christ—whom he did not raise if it is true that the dead are not raised.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if the dead are not raised, then Christ has not been raised.
speaker: Narrator

text: If Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile, and you are still in your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then those also who have died in Christ have perished.
speaker: Narrator

text: If for this life only we have hoped in Christ, we are of all people most to be pitied.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in fact Christ has been raised from the dead, the first fruits of those who have died.
speaker: Narrator

text: For since death came through a human, the resurrection of the dead has also come through a human,
speaker: Narrator

text: for as all die in Adam, so all will be made alive in Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: But each in its own order: Christ the first fruits, then at his coming those who belong to Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then comes the end, when he hands over the kingdom to God the Father, after he has destroyed every ruler and every authority and power.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he must reign until he has put all his enemies under his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The last enemy to be destroyed is death.
speaker: Narrator

text: For “God has put all things in subjection under his feet.” But when it says, “All things are put in subjection,” it is plain that this does not include the one who put all things in subjection under him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all things are subjected to him, then the Son himself will also be subjected to the one who put all things in subjection under him, so that God may be all in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, what will those people do who receive baptism on behalf of the dead? If the dead are not raised at all, why are people baptized on their behalf?
speaker: Narrator

text: And why are we putting ourselves in danger every hour?
speaker: Narrator

text: I die every day! That is as certain, brothers and sisters, as my boasting of you—a boast that I make in Christ Jesus our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I fought with wild animals at Ephesus with a merely human perspective, what would I have gained by it? If the dead are not raised,
“Let us eat and drink,
    for tomorrow we die.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not be deceived:
“Bad company ruins good morals.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Sober up, as you rightly ought to, and sin no more, for some people have no knowledge of God. I say this to your shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: But someone will ask, “How are the dead raised? With what kind of body do they come?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Fool! What you sow does not come to life unless it dies.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as for what you sow, you do not sow the body that is to be but a bare seed, perhaps of wheat or of some other grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God gives it a body as he has chosen and to each kind of seed its own body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not all flesh is alike, but there is one flesh for humans, another for animals, another for birds, and another for fish.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are both heavenly bodies and earthly bodies, but the glory of the heavenly is one thing, and that of the earthly is another.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is one glory of the sun and another glory of the moon and another glory of the stars; indeed, star differs from star in glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it is with the resurrection of the dead. What is sown is perishable; what is raised is imperishable.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is sown in dishonor; it is raised in glory. It is sown in weakness; it is raised in power.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is sown a physical body; it is raised a spiritual body. If there is a physical body, there is also a spiritual body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus it is written, “The first man, Adam, became a living being”; the last Adam became a life-giving spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it is not the spiritual that is first but the physical and then the spiritual.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first man was from the earth, made of dust; the second man is from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: As one of dust, so are those who are of the dust, and as one of heaven, so are those who are of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as we have borne the image of the one of dust, we will also bear the image of the one of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: What I am saying, brothers and sisters, is this: flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God, nor does the perishable inherit the imperishable.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, I will tell you a mystery! We will not all die, but we will all be changed,
speaker: Narrator

text: in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will sound, and the dead will be raised imperishable, and we will be changed.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this perishable body must put on imperishability, and this mortal body must put on immortality.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When this perishable body puts on imperishability and this mortal body puts on immortality, then the saying that is written will be fulfilled:
“Death has been swallowed up in victory.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where, O death, is your victory?
    Where, O death, is your sting?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sting of death is sin, and the power of sin is the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: But thanks be to God, who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, my beloved brothers and sisters, be steadfast, immovable, always excelling in the work of the Lord because you know that in the Lord your labor is not in vain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning the collection for the saints: you should follow the directions I gave to the churches of Galatia.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of every week, each of you is to put aside and save whatever extra you earn, so that collections need not be taken when I come.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when I arrive, I will send any whom you approve with letters to take your gift to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it seems advisable that I should go also, they will accompany me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will visit you after passing through Macedonia—for I intend to pass through Macedonia—
speaker: Narrator

text: and perhaps I will stay with you or even spend the winter, so that you may send me on my way, wherever I go.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do not want to see you now just in passing, for I hope to spend some time with you, if the Lord permits.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will stay in Ephesus until Pentecost,
speaker: Narrator

text: for a wide door for effective work has opened to me, and there are many adversaries.
speaker: Narrator

text: If Timothy comes, see that he has nothing to fear among you, for he is doing the work of the Lord just as I am;
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore let no one despise him. Send him on his way in peace, so that he may come to me, for I am expecting him with the brothers and sisters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning our brother Apollos, I strongly urged him to visit you with the other brothers and sisters, but he was not at all willing to come now. He will come when he has the opportunity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep alert; stand firm in the faith; be courageous; be strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let all that you do be done in love.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, brothers and sisters, you know that members of the household of Stephanas were the first fruits in Achaia, and they have devoted themselves to the service of the saints;
speaker: Narrator

text: I urge you to put yourselves at the service of such people and of everyone who works and toils with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I rejoice at the coming of Stephanas and Fortunatus and Achaicus, because they have made up for your absence,
speaker: Narrator

text: for they refreshed my spirit as well as yours. So give recognition to such persons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The churches of Asia send greetings. Aquila and Prisca, together with the church in their house, greet you warmly in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the brothers and sisters send greetings. Greet one another with a holy kiss.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, Paul, write this greeting with my own hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let anyone be accursed who has no love for the Lord. Our Lord, come!
speaker: Narrator

text: The grace of the Lord Jesus be with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: My love be with all of you in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator
